Award.AwardTitle: Carbon Dioxide and Water Vapor Isotopes in the Atmospheric Boundary Layer
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a study of the transport and dispersion of the stable isotopes of water vapor and carbon dioxide in the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL). The isotopic species of interest are 18O-CO2, 18O-H2O and 13C-CO2. These isotopes offer powerful insights into the carbon and water fluxes on land. This study will explore the extent to which the local atmospheric budgets of these isotopes are linked to wind circulation on land. The primary method to be deployed is a large eddy simulation (LES) model that is dynamically coupled with the isotopic parameterization of land surface processes. LES simulations will be conducted to quantify the relationships of the surface and the entrainment isotopic fluxes to turbulent motion in the ABL. The LES calculations and the isotopic parameterization will be validated against new datasets obtained in a soybean ecosystem and on a tall tower in the Upper Midwest.

The investigators plan several tasks to facilitate use of their results. Animation movies made of the LES results will be integrated into the principal investigator's graduate course on boundary layer meteorology and made available to the public on a Yale website and on YouTube. A post-doctoral fellow and a PhD student will be trained on the state of the art ABL modeling techniques. The isotope-LES model algorithm and the datasets used for model development will be made available to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the proposed project is to investigate the budget of the isotopes of CO2 and water vapor in the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL). ABL is the lowest portion of the atmosphere immediately above the Earth’s surface. The isotopic species of interest are C18OO, H218O, HDO and 13CO2. These species are tracers bearing useful information on CO2 and water vapor sources and their movement in the atmosphere. The research methodology consists of an ABL model called large-eddy simulation model (LES) and analysis of experimental data.

 

The LES simulations reveal that atmospheric C18OO is moderately sensitive to wind. When wind speed above the ABL increases from 1 to 5 m/s, the mid-ABL C18OO  increases by ~0.1 per mil. For comparison, the seasonal variations of atmospheric C18OO are on the order of 1 per mil.

 

The LES simulations also show that entrainment, or exchange of air between the ABL and the free atmosphere above the ABL, plays an important role in the diurnal evolution of water vapor d-excess in the ABL. They show that the maximum d-excess occurring in the mid-afternoon can be 4 per mil larger than the early morning value, consistent with a meta analysis of the vapor d-excess data collected by the PI and his investigators at 6 field sites in North America and in Asia. In other words, contrary to the conventional wisdom, the ABL d-excess is not a good tracer of relative humidity of the marine water vapor source region.

 

In an effort to improve the measurements of atmospheric H18OO and HDO budgets, the PI’s team performed an inter-comparison experiment with four commercial IRIS (infrared isotopic spectroscopy) analyzers to characterize their performance and transferability of calibration methods. Results show that two common calibration methods (discrete liquid water injection and continuous dripping) agree with each other with the tolerance thresholds of 2 per mil for D and 0.1 per mil for 18O. These results provide useful guidance for IRIS developers on how to improve their products.
